CuFe and CuCo supported on pillared clay as catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation into value-added products in one-step Francielle C.F. Marcos a José M. Assaf b Elisabete M. Assaf a ⁎ a University of São Paulo, Av. Trabalhador São-Carlense, 400 − ZIP 13560-970, São Carlos-SP, Brazil University of São Paulo Av. Trabalhador São-Carlense 400 – ZIP São Carlos SP 3560-970 Brazil b Federal University of São Carlos, Rod. W. Luiz, km 235- ZIP 13565-905, São Carlos-SP, Brazil Federal University of São Carlos Rod. W. Luiz km 235- ZIP São Carlos SP 13565-905 Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Value-added products synthesis by the one-step CO2 hydrogenation reaction has attracted much attention of researchers. In this paper, three catalysts: Cu/V-AlPILC,CuFe/V-AlPILC, and CuCo/V-Al PILC, prepared by impregnation method on Al-pillared clay support were studied. The effect of Fe and Co additives on the physicochemical properties of Cu-based catalysts was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), scanning electron microscope (SEM), N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, temperature programmed reduction (TPR), Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2O decomposition, CO2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD), and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy after gaseous pyridine adsorption (Py-FTIR) techniques. These catalysts were evaluated for CO2 hydrogenation into value-added products at temperatures ranging from 250 to 300 °C for 3 h and 40 bar pressure. Stability test was performed at 250 °C for 24 h and 40 bar pressure. The catalytic behavior revealed that a linear relationship does exist between the CO2 conversion with the metallic area. The DME and methanol synthesis showed a correlation with the basic and acid sites. The CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst showed the highest selectivity for methanol and DME at 250 °C. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Copper-based catalyst Value-added products 1 Introduction The capture, storage, and utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) to produce valuable intermediate chemicals and products has gained importance due to the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere. A motivating approach that favors carbon dioxide utilization is CO2 conversion into methanol and dimethyl ether (DME) [1–14]. The industrial methanol synthesis by catalytic system occurs over CuZn/Al2O3 catalyst from synthesis gas (CO + H2) with a small amount (<5%) of CO2 [3,11,15,16].Currently, several studies have been proposed for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation for a number of reasons: thermodynamic reaction is more favorable at high pressure and low temperature, the use of CO2 waste can mitigate greenhouse problems due to a high methanol production demand. In addition, methanol is an important chemical that can be directly used as fuel or feedstock for several organic materials, such as formaldehyde, methyl tertiary-butyl ether (MTBE), acetic acid, methyl methacrylate (MMA), as a solvent, and DME [1,2,7,17–22]. Dimethyl ether catalytic synthesis (DME) can occur via two paths: a. conventional process, by two separately reactors, with a catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO or CO2 hydrogenation and another one with an acid catalyst for methanol dehydration (for example γ-Al2O3 catalyst) or b. by one-step with a bifunctional catalyst with metallic and acid-base sites [8,23]. In this case, the DME synthesis is more thermodynamically favorable than the conventional process [24,25]. Moreover, DME has demonstrated great importance from an industrial viewpoint. It can be used as chemical feedstock and also as an alternative to conventional diesel [2,25–29]. Despite extensive researches regarding CO2 hydrogenation for value-added products over Cu-based catalysts, a catalyst with a high selectivity and stability for methanol or DME has not yet been achieved. Furthermore, it is well known from the literature that sintering process and Cu agglomeration of metallic sites can occur on the catalyst during reaction [17,28,30–33]. However, bimetallic combinations of Cu with small amounts of Fischer Tropsch catalysts (FT), such as Fe or Co, supported on acid-base solid could be key to the development of a new bifunctional catalyst (containing both metallic and acid-base sites) for one-step synthesis reactions[30,34–36]. Co and Fe are usually the active metals used as catalysts for commercial FT synthesis[19,30,37]. Chen et al. reported the presence of small iron species particles in copper catalysts effectively prevents Cu sintering and improves the copper surface area. Moreover, the presence of Fe inhibited copper surfaces oxidation [30,34]. Cobalt-based catalyst has also exhibited activity for CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The difference between Fe and Co catalysts in FT reaction can be explained by a different inhibition for methane formation [19,30,38]. On the other hand, the acid sites present in the catalyst bear the main responsibility for DME production by methanol dehydration reaction [17,39–43]. As reported in the literature, modified clays (montmorillonite) are active for methanol dehydration reaction into DME due to the presence of acid sites [24,39]. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the synergistic effect between Cu-Fe and Cu-Co supported on Al pillaring clay, V-Al PILC, during the one-step CO2 hydrogenation reaction for value-added products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis CuFe and CuCo supported on Al-pillared clay (V-Al-PILC) catalysts were synthesized by simultaneous incipient-wetness impregnation method. The V-Al-PILC support was synthesized by pillaring montmorillonite (V) with keggin ion (Al13), as reported in more detail by Marcos et al. [44]. A total 10 wt.% Cu loading and 5 wt.% Fe or Co were supported on V-Al-PILC. Cu, Fe, and Co precursors were Cu (NO3)2·3H2O (Alfa Aesar), Fe (NO3)3·9H2O (Vetec), and Co (NO3)2·6H2O (Synth), respectively. After nitrates impregnation, the resulting mixture was dried for 24 h at 80 °C and calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. Additionally, one catalyst containing the only Cu on V-Al PILC was used as reference, details regarding this synthesis are described elsewhere [39].The catalysts were named CuFe/V-Al PILC, CuCo/V-Al PILC, and Cu/V-Al PILC.To get the active form, the catalysts were reduced under H2 flowing at 30 mL/min−1 for 1 h and the temperature condition was determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Multiflex diffractometer using Cu Kα (1.5406 Å) radiation source and 2θ range from 10° to 80° at a 10° min−1 rate. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) measurements were performed using a Link QX 2000 EDS analyzer coupled to an LEO 440 scanning electron microscope equipped with a tungsten filament and coupled to an energy dispersive X-ray detector.The morphology of the fresh and spent catalysts was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) carried out in an LEO 440 microscope with an Oxford detector. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were performed in a Quanta Chrome Nova − 1000 model gas adsorption analyzer. Firstly, the samples were outgassed under vacuum during 4 h at 250 °C. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (B.E.T) method. The micropores area and volume were determined by t-plot analysis and the pore size distribution was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (B.J.H). The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was performed in a quartz reactor using a Micromeritics Pulse ChemiSorb 2750 equipment.100 mg of the sample was reduced with a 10% H2/Ar (v/v) mixture, flowing at 30 mL/min−1 from room temperature to 900 °C at a 10 °C/min−1 heating rate H2 consumption was monitored by a TCD detector. The metallic surface area of copper (S Cu) was performed in a quartz reactor using an analytical multipurpose system by an N2O decomposition method, similar to the one described by Marcos et al. [39]. Firstly, 100 mg of sample was reduced in a H2/Ar (1.96% v/v) mixture, flowing at 30 mL/min−1 at 300 °C for 1 h. After that, the sample was cooled down to 60 °C and a N2O/He (10% v/v) gas mixture was carried out at a 30 mL/min−1 flow rate for 30 min. Physically adsorbed N2O was removed by N2 purging flowing at 30 mL/min−1 for 1 h and then, the sample was cooled down to 25 °C under N2 flow and a new reduction cycle was then performed to reduce the Cu2O surface to CuO. The TEM images were performed using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 instrument at 200 kV high resolution. The samples were dispersed in isopropyl alcohol and deposited on Ni grids. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy data were collected using a Scienta Omicron ESCA+ spectrometer equipped with an EA 125 hemispherical analyzer. The spectra were taken using monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation with an energy steps of 0.03 eV for the high-resolution spectra. For the data analysis, the binding energy was corrected by adjusting the C 1 s peak position to 284.5 eV for each sample surface. The Casa XPS software with a 70:30 Gaussian Lorentzian product function and Shirley background subtraction were used for peak deconvolution. CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analysis was carried out using the same device for TPR measurements.100 mg of sample was reduced in situ with a H2/Ar (10%v/v) mixture, flowing at 25 mL/min−1 from room temperature to 300 °C for 1 h at a 10 °C/min−1 heating rate. Afterwards, the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C for CO2 adsorption under Ar flowing at 25 mL/min−1. Physically adsorbed CO2 was removed by Ar purging for 1 h in the same flow and then cooled down to 25 °C. Then, the CO2-TPD experiment was performed under Ar flow (20 mL/min−1) up to 900 °C. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was similar to the experiments above. The experiment was carried out on an AutoChem II 2920 Micromerictics chemisorption analyzer. Firstly, the sample was pretreated at 500 °C in a He atmosphere flowing at 50 mL/min−1 for 30 min, cooled down to 25 °C and in situ reductions under a H2/He (10% v/v) mixture, flowing at 30 mL/min−1 for 1 h at 300 °C. After that, the sample was cooled down to 120 °C under He flowing at 30 mL/min−1 and then, the NH3 adsorption was initiated with a NH3/He (15% v/v) mixture at 20 kPa for 30 min and subsequently cooled down to 50 °C under He flow. Physically adsorbed NH3 was removed by He purging flowing at 30 mL/min−1for 1 h. Afterward, the NH3-TPD experiment was performed under He flow (30 mL/min−1) up to 900 °C. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy after gaseous pyridine adsorption (Py-FTIR) analysis was recorded on a Prestigi-21 spectrophotometer. Firstly, 50 mg of sample was pretreated under N2 flowing at 100 mL/min−1 for 1 h in a tubular furnace at 300 °C. After that, the sample was cooled down to 150 °C under the same gas and then, the gaseous pyridine (Py) was adsorbed on the sample for 4 h. Physically adsorbed Py was removed by N2 purging flowing at 100 mL/min−1 for 1 h. The sample spectrum was recorded within the 1800–1400 cm−1 range and transmittance mode. 2.3 Reaction setup CO2 hydrogenation reactions were evaluated in a high-pressure reactor (Parr instruments) at 40 bar pressure. For reaction studies, 200 mg of catalyst diluted with the same amount of inert SiC (Alfa Aesar) were reduced with H2 (30 mL/min−1) for 1 h at 300 °C. After reduction, the experiments were performed at temperatures ranging from 250 to 300 °C and with a H2: CO2 = 3:1 (molar ratio) mixture. All catalysts were evaluated for both temperatures. The flow rate of reagents was individually controlled by an electronic mass flow controller (Brooks 0254). In the reaction system, a back pressure valve was installed in series with the reactor. All post-reactor lines and valves were heated to 180 °C to prevent product condensation. Effluent products were analyzed online in a gas chromatograph Agilent 7890 A model equipped with two 6-port valves and a 10-port valve, TCD and FID detectors and three columns, HP pona, Plot-Q, and HP molesiev. CO2 conversion and selectivity were quantified by the external standard method using peak area normalization. Both conversion (XCO2) and selectivity were calculated as reported in details elsewhere [39]. 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns of bimetallic catalysts at room temperature are shown in Fig. 1 . Data matching can be seen for both catalysts with the standard CuO pattern corresponding to the monoclinic phase (JCPDS NO.89-2530). In addition, peaks typical of montmorillonite (Mt) and quartz (Qz) phases were also identified. Besides that, as shown in Fig. 1 (A) and (B), no Cu2O diffraction peaks crystallites can be found for all studied catalysts. Fe presence for the CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst was not possible to be clearly identified. The mean Fe3O4 diffraction peak (JCPDS NO.03-0863) appears overlapping on the CuO diffraction. The presence of Co on CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst was identified through diffraction peaks corresponding to Co3O4 spinel structure (JCPDS NO.42-1467) [45,46]. Table 1 shows the average mass percentage of Cu, Fe, and Co metals impregnated on V-Al PILC support, determined by EDS analysis, BET specific surface area, micropore area, and micropore catalysts volume. It can be noted that the real individual elements contents impregnated on V-Al PILC support, are close to the nominal values. Also, all standard deviations were less than 1, indicating a close real percentage and uniform dispersion. The active phase impregnation (Cu, Fe, and Co) on the V-Al PILC support, reduced its specific surface area, (S B.E.T = 245 m2 g−1)[44]. This specific surface area decrease can be attributed to the covering of the support by impregnated metal particles deposited in the matrix pores. Besides that, it was observed that Cu-Fe or Cu-Co addition favors specific surface area increase when compared with the sample containing only impregnated Cu (Cu/V-Al PILC S B.E.T = 52 m2 g−1)[39]. The CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst showed the largest specific surface area (B.E.T and t-plot) and micropore volume in comparison with CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst. Fig. 2 displays the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distribution catalysts profiles. The catalysts showed N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms that could be ascribed as type II, according to IUPAC classification. In the high-pressure region, P/P0 > 0.4, hysteresis loops were observed probably due to a capillary condensation phenomenon. This is typical of aggregated powders such as clays [44]. The CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst showed a considerable increase in the N2 adsorbed for P/P0 = 0.2 when compared with the CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst. This is in good agreement with the specific surface area value in Table 1. The pore size distribution for both samples is centered with a higher frequency between 15 and 22 Å, corresponding to micro and mesoporous materials. Fig. 3 displays the bimetallic catalysts TPR profiles. The CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst showed four well-defined reduction peaks. At 220 °C the reduction peak can be related to the reduction of structurally dispersed CuO species to Cu0. Also, at 280 °C the reduction peak can be assigned to CuO species interacted with Fe, as proposed by XRD analysis Fig. 1 A). This implies that the Fe added facilitates the reducibility of CuO. In addition, this suggests that there is a synergistic effect between Fe and Cu. On the other hand, from 350 °C the peaks can be ascribed to hematite reduction into magnetite and then, the magnetite reduction into metallic iron (Eq. (1)). Fe is present in natural clay and it was also added by impregnation method [39,47]. (1) α-Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → Fe0 CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst TPR profile showed the onset reduction temperature similar to Cu/V-Al PILC catalyst (∼300 °C) for CuO reduction into Cu0. Also, at the same temperature, the CO3O4 may be being reduced to Co0. At a higher temperature (>350 °C) the reduction peak was ascribed to Fe reduction present in the support. Hence, the catalysts were examined using XRD analysis after activation process in order to confirm CuO, Fe2O3, and Co3O4 reduction. In order to investigate the Cu, Fe, and Co phases present on reduction conditions for catalytic tests, the samples were reduced at temperatures of interest and evaluated by XRD analysis (Figs. 4 and 5 ). As shown in Fig. 4 (A) for CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst at 220 °C and 280 °C, the CuO present in the sample was reduced to Cu0. On the other hand, CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst at 300 °C showed that both CuO and Co3O4 phases were reduced to Cu0 and Co0. This corroborates with the TPR analysis (Fig. 3). To evaluate the metallic surface area of the catalyst − sites responsible for methanol hydrogenation reaction the samples were measured by N2O chemisorption, data seen in Table 2 . The sample containing only the clay-supported Cu, Cu/V-AlPILC, showed a metallic copper surface area S Cu = 17 m2 g−1[39]. As evident from the data, Fe or Co interaction with Cu favored the metallic surface area increase. The CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst displayed both the highest metallic surface area and metallic dispersion. To evaluate copper, iron and cobalt dispersion at smaller length scales, STEM images were obtained (Fig. 6 ) for CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC catalysts. EDX mapping of Cu, Fe and Co was also carried out with the STEM to confirm the distribution Cu, Fe and Co in rich regions. This analysis showed that all elements added (Cu, Fe and Co) on the support (V-Al PILC) were homogeneously distributed. Besides that, the particles of Cu and Fe oxides and Cu and Co oxides are an intimate interface contact for both catalysts. Details about the particle size of Cu, Fe and Co in this analysis is not possible because it is difficult to straightforwardly distinguish between the two phases formed for both catalysts. In addition, for the CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst it is observed that Cu and Co are distributed over the particle of the support. In order to understand the interaction between Cu-Fe and Cu-Co species on the surfaces of the as-prepared samples, CuFe/V-Al PILC, CuCo/V-Al PILC and Cu/V-Al PILC samples were investigated by XPS technique (Fig. 7 and Table 3 ). All samples showed shake-up satellite peaks characteristic of Cu2+. Cu/V-AlPILC sample showed 2p3/2 peaks at 933.04 eV and 935.15 eV, respectively, indicating that there are two kinds of Cu2+ species in this sample. The Cu 2p3/2 peak at 933.04 eV is related to CuO, while that at 935.15 eV peak is attributed to Cu-O-M (M = Si). Furthermore, for CuO-SiO2 based materials is observed a shift the binding energy (B.E) of Cu 2p3/2 to higher values (935.15 eV) [48,49]. This suggests that copper can be more interacted with the Si on the surface of this catalyst. However, CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC samples exhibited only one peak for Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 at approximate of 934.0 eV and 953.96 eV, respectively. The addition of Fe and Co on Cu/V-Al PILC could have caused a decrease in the outer-shell electron density of Cu. As observed, both CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC samples presented a shift of the B.E. for higher binding energy for Cu+2. This shift is indicative of a charge transfer from the metal Cu toward the Fe or Co. Table 3 displays the surface composition of catalysts obtained from XPS analysis. The catalysts showed the following order of Cu contents on the surface: CuFe/V-Al PILC > CuCo/V-Al PILC > Cu/V-Al PILC. This data corroborates with the metallic area of catalysts, determined by N2O decomposition method (Table 2). This suggests that Cu species present on Cu/V-Al PILC sample can be more interacted with the support, as well explain the lower amount of Cu on the surface for this catalyst. Both CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC samples showed the higher Cu contents on the surface, respectively. In addition, it was observed by TEM analysis (Fig. 6) that Cu-Fe and Cu-Co particles are in an intimate interface contact. This confirms the synergysm between Cu-Fe and Cu-Co species. Is important to highlight the Cu-Fe synergistic effect, as shown in TPR analysis (Fig. 3), as well the higher content of active phase on the surface for this catalyst, as shown in XPS analysis (Table 3). Then, this can impose a beneficial influence on the catalytic activity for alcohol synthesis. In order to investigate acid-base sites distribution in the reduced catalyst, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD measurements were performed, as shown in Figs. 8–9 . The density of acid-base sites data is summarized in Tables 4 and 5 . The presence of Acid-base sites has a direct influence on the CO2 activation process and for a product from alcohol dehydration. The CO2 desorption profiles of catalysts are similar and clearly display the presence of three different strength of basic sites assigned as weak, moderate, and strong with different distributions and densities, as shown in Fig. 8A) and Table 4. In addition, all catalysts exhibited basic sites (>70%) stronger than weak and medium sites. It is important to note that Fe and Co presence has not affected the CO2-TPD profiles when compared with the Cu/V-Al PILC catalyst, but have affected the basic sites total density (8.19 × 10−4mmol g−1) [39]. In addition, it is observed that bimetallic catalysts have not presented a significant difference between them in basic sites density. NH3-TPD profiles of bimetallic catalysts showed curves that were deconvoluted by Gaussian function into peaks with different acid strengths; weak, medium, and strong with different distributions. The NH3-TPD profiles were similar to CO2-TPD profiles. However, a number of acid sites were higher than basic sites, as showed in Tables 4 and 5. It is important to highlight that the presence of Fe favored acid sites increase when compared with the other catalysts, CuCo/V-Al PILC and Cu/V-Al PILC (2.41 and 2.37 mmol g−1, respectively). In addition, the CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst presented acid sites weaker than the CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst. The weak-strength acid sites are more effective for selective DME synthesis [50]. FTIR experiment using pyridine as probe molecule was performed in order to distinguish the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites present in the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7. The catalysts spectra displayed four bands assigned to pyridine vibration modes coordinated to the Lewis acid sites at 1450, 1490, and 1610 cm−1 and Brønsted acid sites at 1490 and 1636 cm−1[27,51,52]. It has been noted that bimetallic catalysts showed one more band at 1610 cm−1 assigned to Lewis acid site when compared with Cu/V-Al PILC catalyst [39]. In addition, the CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst presented a more intense Lewis band (at 1450 cm−1) when compared to the CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst. The catalytic result of CO2 hydrogenation is presented in Figs. 10 and 11 . In terms of CO2 conversion, X (CO2) %, it has gradually increased with temperature, the highest value (∼ 21°) was reached for the CuCo/V-AlPILC catalyst. As showed in Fig. 10 B), the CO2 conversion was directly linked with the metallic area. The interaction between Cu-Fe and Cu-Co favored the metallic surface area increase, (Table 2). According to the literature, Cu0 particles presenting catalysts are the active phase for CO2 hydrogenation [29,43,53–56]. In terms of product distribution, the main products obtained were methanol, DME, CO, methane (C1) and C2-C4 traces, Fig. 11 . The reaction temperature increase has not favored the increase of either methanol or DME, but it favored the CO increase (byproduct). The decrease in methanol synthesis (Eq. (2)) with the increase of temperature can be linked with competitive reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. (3)). Temperature raising favors RWGS reaction as it is an endothermic reaction [39,54,56]. The mechanism in the RWGS for CO formation can be explained by Cu0 oxidation in the presence of CO2 generating CO, whereas Cu1+ is reduced in the presence of H2 to Cu0 forming H2O [34]. Moreover, the increase of temperature also favored methanation reaction (Eq. (4)), a thermodynamically favorable reaction (ΔG298K = −130.8 kJ mol−1) [30,39]. This can be explained by higher selectivity for methane during the CO2 reaction. Furthermore, it was noted that the catalyst with cobalt (CuCo/V-Al PILC) presented more methane than the other ones. (2) C O 2 + 3 H ⇌ C H 3 O H + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = − 49.4 k J m o l − 1 (3) C O 2 + H 2 ⇌ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = + 41.2 k J m o l − 1 (4) C O 2 + 4 H 2 → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 K = − 252.9 k J m o l − 1 It is also important to favor the CO2 conversion into methanol as well as the basicity catalyst sites. According to literature, CO2 is activated on the basic sites [18,39]. As reported in this study by CO2-TPD analysis (Fig. 8 (A) and Table 4), methanol selectivity increases with the medium and strong basic sites increase. These data are in good agreement with Bonura et al. [57]. The CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst showed the highest selectivity for methanol at 250 °C. In terms of direct DME synthesis (CO2-to-DME), the reactions involve methanol synthesis (Eq. (2)), reverse water-gas shift (Eq. (3)), and methanol synthesis by CO hydrogenation reaction (Eq. (5)) in the presence of basic and metallic sites, followed by methanol dehydration in the presence of acid sites (Eq. (6)). In other words, this product is synthesized by a one-step bifunctional catalyst. (5) C O + 2 H 2 ⇋ C H 3 O H Δ H 298 K = − 90.6 k J m o l − 1 (6) 2 C H 3 O H ⇌ C H 3 O C H 3 + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = − 23.4 k J m o l − 1 Considering the properties reported for acid sites, (Table 4), a correlation to DME selectivity with weak and medium acid sites density has been identified. The CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst showed the higher density of weak and medium sites when compared with the CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst, (∼1.4 mmol−1 and 1.0 mmol−1), respectively. These results are in good agreement with Bonura et al. [57]. In terms of acid sites types (Lewis and Brønsted), it was not possible to correlate it with the DME synthesis, since the obtained data were similar for all evaluated catalysts. The highest selectivity value for DME (∼ 40°) was reached for CuFe/V-AlPILC catalyst at 250 °C. It is important to note that Cu-catalysts modified with Fe and Co and FT catalysts, are studied for higher alcohols (C2+OH) synthesis by CO and CO2 reactions hydrogenation [34,35,47,58,59]. However, C2+OH formation was not observed in this work. The absence of higher alcohols can be related to a high acid sites density, when compared to the basic sites present in the catalysts, as reported in Tables 4 and 5. According to Heracleous et al., the reduction of acid sites and the increase of the basic sites in the catalyst provide higher alcohols [60]. Furthermore, the data obtained indicate that methanol is being rapidly transformed into DME, as presented in Fig. 11. During the CO2 hydrogenation catalysts can suffer a fast deactivation via two possible causes: by coke deposition on the active, metallic, and acid sites (Eq. (7)), or by catalyst metallic sites sintering [19–21,26,29,47,61]. In addition, specifically for the CO2-to-DME reaction, another possibility for poor DME selectivity can occur by water molecules adsorption on Lewis acid sites [26]. This is another reason why the yield methanol and DME can be reduced over time. (7) C O + C O → C O ( s ) + C O 2 Δ R H 300 ° C = 173.5 k J m o l − 1 XRD and SEM measurements were carried out in order to evaluate the crystalline phases and the morphology of catalysts after the reaction, as shown in Figs. 12 and 13 and 13. XRD analysis of both spent catalysts revealed prominent peaks characteristic of silicon carbide (SiC) and metallic copper. For CuCo/V-Al PILC catalyst it was also observed around 2Ө∼ 21.8 and 27.6° peaks characteristic of SiO2 (JCPDS NO. 86-1565). No carbon presence has been identified. This indicates that carbon formation did not occur during the experiment condition tested in the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation and that copper remained in the active metallic state. Catalysts morphology before (fresh) and after CO2 hydrogenation (spent) was investigated by scanning electron micrographs (SEM) with mapping, as shown in Fig. 13 . SEM measurements showed that both catalysts presented morphology with undefined shape and a non-uniform particle size distribution. In addition, a significant change in the morphology between CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V- AlPILC fresh catalysts was noted. As compared with the V- Al PILC support, it has been observed that the morphology with undefined shape and non-uniform particle size distribution are characteristic of the support [44]. Fresh bimetallic catalysts mapping shows that impregnated elements are well dispersed on the support and corresponds to the smaller particle sizes. Besides, the CuCo/V-AlPILC catalyst displays a better Cu dispersion when compared to CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst. These micrographs are in good agreement with Cu dispersion data obtained by N2O chemisorption (Table 2). After CO2 hydrogenation, the samples’ morphology was altered and no carbon formation was observed. This result is consistent with XRD analysis of the spent catalysts, (Fig. 12). The stability of CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC during CO2 hydrogenation is presented in Fig. 14 . It can be seen that the conversion of CO2 remained constant during the catalytic test and showed a medium conversion ((%)x¯CO2) of 8.5 and 14.3 for CuFe/V-Al PILC and CuCo/V-Al PILC, respectively, for 24 h. However, the selectivity of DME decreases slightly after 15 h of time on stream for both catalysts, which may be due to deactivation of acid sites by adsorption of the water formed during the dehydration of the methanol reaction (Eq. (6)) on Lewis acid sites. This is in good agreement with the literature, as the presence of excess water has been shown to shift the equilibrium of the methanol dehydration reaction and reduce the activity and selectivity of DME [17,25,62]. In addition, there is a prominent increase of CO as a reaction byproduct after 15 h for both catalysts. 4 Conclusion The present study showed that bimetallic combinations of Cu with Fe and/or Co favored the increase of specific surface area and specific metallic area. The catalytic behavior reveals that a linear relationship does exist between CO2 conversions with the metallic copper area. The DME and methanol synthesis showed a correlation with the basic and acid sites. The increase of temperature did not favor methanol and DME synthesis. The best performance in methanol and DME production was obtained with CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst at 250 °C due to the synergistic effect between iron and copper species, which contributes to the enhancement of selectivity towards methanol and DME. coredata.dc:description: Value-added products synthesis by the one-step CO2 hydrogenation reaction has attracted much attention of researchers. In this paper, three catalysts: Cu/V-AlPILC,CuFe/V-AlPILC, and CuCo/V-Al PILC, prepared by impregnation method on Al-pillared clay support were studied. The effect of Fe and Co additives on the physicochemical properties of Cu-based catalysts was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), scanning electron microscope (SEM), N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, temperature programmed reduction (TPR), Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2O decomposition, CO2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD), and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy after gaseous pyridine adsorption (Py-FTIR) techniques. These catalysts were evaluated for CO2 hydrogenation into value-added products at temperatures ranging from 250 to 300 °C for 3 h and 40 bar pressure. Stability test was performed at 250 °C for 24 h and 40 bar pressure. The catalytic behavior revealed that a linear relationship does exist between the CO2 conversion with the metallic area. The DME and methanol synthesis showed a correlation with the basic and acid sites. The CuFe/V-Al PILC catalyst showed the highest selectivity for methanol and DME at 250 °C.
coredata.dc:title: CuFe and CuCo supported on pillared clay as catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation into value-added products in one-step
